title: 113_s371
content: The Act is titled the "Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park Establishment Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park Establishment Act aims to preserve and interpret the industrial heritage of the region for future generations. It also supports the preservation of the landscape features and educates the public about the significance of the area. The Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park Establishment Act aims to preserve the significance of the Blackstone River Valley in the United States and support a network of partners for the protection and management of related resources and facilities in the area. The Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park Establishment Act defines key terms such as National Heritage Corridor, Park, Secretary, and States. The Act establishes the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park is established in the States, including historic sites like Blackstone River State Park, Old Slater Mill National Historic Landmark District, Slatersville Historic District, and others as described in a study report. Land acquisition and park boundaries are also addressed. The Blackstone Canal is part of the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park. The Secretary can acquire land for the park boundary through donation, purchase, or exchange. Once enough land is acquired, a boundary map will be published in the Federal Register. Other resources can also be included in the park boundary. The Park boundary can be adjusted when acquiring land or entering agreements, with maps published in the Federal Register. Maps are available for public inspection, and the Secretary can acquire up to 10 acres in Woonsocket, Rhode Island for administrative facilities. The Secretary administers land within the Park boundary in accordance with laws applicable to the National Park System, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. Land owned by States can only be acquired through donation. The Secretary prepares a general management plan for the Park in consultation with States and interested parties, considering preexisting visitor facilities and recreational opportunities in the National Heritage Corridor. The Secretary may provide technical assistance, visitor services, interpretive tours, and related sites including the Captain Wilbur Kelly House, Blackstone River State Park, Museum of Work and Culture, River Bend Farm/Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park, Worcester Blackstone Visitor Center, Route 295 Visitor Center, and Blackstone River Bikeway. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with various entities to provide technical assistance, interpretation, and educational programs in the National Heritage Corridor, including sites outside the Park's boundary. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements to provide assistance, interpretation, and educational programs in historic sites and districts. Funding may cover up to 50% of the cost for resource protection projects in the Park, with a matching requirement for Federal funds. The Secretary may provide assistance for historic sites and districts through cooperative agreements with a matching requirement for Federal funds. Reimbursement for project conversion or disposal inconsistent with the section's purposes will be required by the Secretary. Congress dedicates the Park to John H. Chafee, former United States Senator from Rhode Island, in recognition of his role in preserving the resources of the Blackstone River Valley and heritage corridor named after him, as well as his decades of service to Rhode Island and the United States. Public access to the resources covered by cooperative agreements must be provided. The Park is dedicated to John H. Chafee for his role in preserving the Blackstone River Valley resources. A memorial will be displayed in the Park to recognize his contributions for the people of Rhode Island and the United States. SEC. 5. JOHN H. CHAFEE BLACKSTONE RIVER VALLEY NATIONAL HERITAGE CORRIDOR AMENDMENTS. Public Law 99-647 is amended to update the boundaries of the John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor and designate a local coordinating entity. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor is updated by amending Public Law 99-647 to designate a local coordinating entity, Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor, Inc., for the implementation of the Cultural Heritage and Land Management Plan. The local coordinating entity may use funds to make grants to the States of Massachusetts and Rhode Island for carrying out the management plan. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor allows for cooperative agreements with States, organizations, and individuals, hiring staff with expertise in various areas, obtaining funds from any source, and contracting for goods and services. The John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor allows for cooperative agreements with entities for technical assistance and other activities supporting the corridor's purposes. The Secretary shall enter into a memorandum of understanding with the local coordinating entity to ensure the appropriate transition of management of the Corridor from the Commission to the local coordinating entity and coordination regarding the implementation of the Cultural Heritage and Land Management Plan. The Secretary shall enter into a memorandum of understanding with the local coordinating entity to ensure the appropriate transition of management of the Corridor from the Commission to the local coordinating entity and coordination regarding the implementation of the Cultural Heritage and Land Management Plan. Additionally, amendments are made to subsections (a) and (b) of the Act, and subsection (c) is removed. SEC. 11 states that references to the Commission in certain sections should be considered as references to the local coordinating entity. SEC. 6 authorizes appropriations for sections 2 through 4.
